text: In 1967, two mathematicians published PhD dissertations independently disproving the same thirteen-year-old conjecture (the common fixed point problem).
The center squeeze voting phenomenon has been blamed for costing Gary Johnson the 2016 US presidential election.
Eratosthenes, the librarian of the Great Library of Alexandria, was nicknamed 'Beta' ('Second') because he wasn't considered the best at anything.
There are more possible iterations of a game of chess than there are atoms in the observable universe.
If you could fold a piece of paper 42 times, it would reach the Moon; 103 folds would make it thicker than the observable universe.
If you shuffle a deck of cards properly, the order you get has almost certainly never existed before in the history of the universe and likely never will again.
There are more possible games of chess than atoms in the observable universe.
A jiffy is an actual unit of time — 1/100th of a second.
Cows kill more people per year than sharks.
A jiffy is 1/100th of a second.
Cows kill more people annually than sharks.
Vending machines kill more people annually than sharks.
There are more possible chess games than atoms in the universe.
There are more potential chess games than atoms in the observable universe.
There are more ways to arrange a deck of 52 cards than there are atoms in the observable universe.
Pi has been calculated to over 100 trillion digits, but 39 digits are enough to calculate the circumference of the observable universe to within the width of a hydrogen atom.
If you fold a piece of paper 42 times, it would reach the moon; 103 times would make it larger than the observable universe.
The number 0.999... repeating is exactly equal to 1, not approximately — this has been mathematically proven.
There are exactly 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 possible Rubik's Cube positions, but any can be solved in 20 moves or less.
The largest known prime number has over 24 million digits and would take months to recite aloud.
The Fibonacci sequence appears naturally in pinecones, sunflowers, shells, and even galaxy spirals.
Graham's number is so large that if you tried to imagine all its digits, your brain would collapse into a black hole.
Zero was invented independently in India and by the Maya, but the Romans never had a symbol for it.
In a room of 23 people, there's a 50% chance that two share a birthday; with 70 people, it's 99.9%.
The number 1,729 is called the 'Hardy-Ramanujan number' because it's the smallest number expressible as the sum of two cubes in two different ways.
A googol is 10^100, but a googolplex is 10^googol — so large that writing it out would exceed the size of the universe.
There are infinitely many types of infinity, and some infinities are larger than others.
The Monty Hall problem proves that switching doors gives you a 2/3 chance of winning, not 1/2 — counterintuitive but true.
Every even number greater than 2 is the sum of two prime numbers — Goldbach's conjecture, unproven for 280 years.
The number 7 appears more frequently in rolling dice than any other because there are more combinations that sum to 7.
A perfect shuffle of a deck of 52 cards 8 times returns it to its original order.
The golden ratio (1.618...) appears in the Parthenon, Leonardo's Vitruvian Man, and DNA's double helix.
Benford's Law says that in many real datasets, the number 1 appears as the leading digit about 30% of the time.
The word 'algorithm' comes from Al-Khwarizmi, a 9th-century Persian mathematician.
There's no largest prime number — Euclid proved this over 2,000 years ago.
If you wrote out every whole number in words, you wouldn't use the letter 'a' until you reached 'one thousand.'
The number 1 isn't considered prime because it would break the fundamental theorem of arithmetic.
In binary, all numbers are represented using only 0s and 1s — the entire internet runs on this system.
The sum of all natural numbers (1+2+3+...) technically equals -1/12 in certain mathematical frameworks.
Roman numerals have no symbol for zero, which made complex math nearly impossible.
Perfect numbers are equal to the sum of their divisors — 6 is perfect because 1+2+3=6.
The Fibonacci sequence starts with the numbers 0 and 1, and each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two.
e (Euler's number, ~2.718) appears in compound interest, probability, and radioactive decay.
Imaginary numbers, like the square root of -1, are essential for describing electrical circuits and quantum mechanics.
The ancient Egyptians only used unit fractions (1/n) and had to express 2/5 as 1/3 + 1/15.
A centillion is 10^303 in America but 10^600 in Europe due to different naming conventions.
The number 142857 is magical — multiply it by 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6, and you get the same digits in a different order.
There are exactly 13 ways to arrange a set of parentheses with 3 pairs: (()()) vs ((())).
The number 23 is considered prime, but the sum of its digits (5) is also prime — it's a 'super-prime.'
Euler's identity (e^(iπ) + 1 = 0) connects five fundamental constants and is called 'the most beautiful equation.'
The ancient Babylonians used base-60, which is why we have 60 seconds in a minute and 360 degrees in a circle.
Cantor proved that there are more real numbers between 0 and 1 than there are whole numbers in existence.
The Mandelbrot set contains infinite complexity at every scale — you can zoom forever and never see the same pattern.
Kaprekar's constant is 6174 — subtract the smallest arrangement of any 4-digit number from the largest, and you'll always reach 6174.
A paradox in set theory: 'the set of all sets that don't contain themselves' — does it contain itself?
The average person spends 6 months of their life waiting at red lights.
A jiffy is an actual unit of time: 1/100th of a second.
Vending machines kill more people than sharks annually.
There are more possible iterations of a chess game than atoms in the known universe.
More people are killed each year by vending machines than by sharks.
The average American spends about 6 months of their life waiting at red lights.
The average person spends about 2 years of their life on phone calls.
